qas.question: What were the things that post-punk really got into?
What are non-rock styles that post-punk used as inspiration?

answers.text: dub, electronic music, disco, noise, jazz, krautrock, world music and the avant-garde

qas.question: What aesthetic did Matthew Bannister associate with post-punk?
What music did post-punk end to reject?

answers.text: high cultural references of 1960s rock artists

qas.question: As a movement, post-punk has been characterized by its conceptual assault on what conventions?
What does post-punk reject any of which are perceived as being traditionalist, hegemonic, or rockist?
What is one of the foundational aspects post-punk is deeply favorable towards?
How did post-punk artists once again approach the studio?
What references did post-punk artists specifically reject of the 1960s rock artists?
What movement was characterized by its "conceptualassult" on punk conventions?

plausible_answers.text: dub, electronic music, disco, noise, jazz, krautrock, world music and the avant-garde

qas.question: What are rock styles that post-punk used for insperation?
What aesthetic did Mathew Bannister associate with punk?
What did punk asrtist embrace from 1960's rock?

plausible_answers.text: particular brands of glam, art rock and "[the] dark undercurrent of '60s music".

qas.question: What music styles where rejected by post-punk?
What was something nobody in post-punk focused on?
What aesthetic did Matthew Bannister not associate with post-punk?

plausible_answers.text: high cultural references of 1960s rock artists

qas.question: What did post-punk artists support most?
What type of music did post-punk inspire most?

context: Though the music varied widely between regions and artists, the <b9_0>post-punk movement<b9_0/> has been characterized by its "conceptual assault" on <a4_0>rock<a4_0/> conventions and rejection of <a5_0>aesthetics<a5_0/> perceived of as traditionalist, hegemonic or rockist in favor of <a0_0><a6_0><b14_0>experimentation<a6_0/> with production techniques<b14_0/><a0_0/> and non-rock musical styles such as <a1_0><b10_0>dub, electronic music, disco, noise, jazz, krautrock, world music and the <b15_0>avant-garde<b15_0/><b10_0/><a1_0/>. While post-punk musicians often avoided or intentionally obscured conventional influences, previous musical styles did serve as touchstones for the movement, including <b13_0>particular brands of glam, art rock and "[the] dark undercurrent of '60s music".<b13_0/>[nb 1] According to Reynolds, artists once again approached the studio <a7_0>as an instrument<a7_0/>, using new recording methods and pursuing novel sonic territories. Author Matthew Bannister wrote that post-punk artists rejected the <a3_0><a8_0><b12_0><b16_0>high cultural<a8_0/> references<b12_0/> of 1960s rock artists<b16_0/><a3_0/> like the Beatles and Bob Dylan as well as paradigms that defined "<b17_0>rock<b17_0/> as progressive, as art, as 'sterile' studio perfectionism ... by adopting an <a2_0><b11_0>avant-garde<b11_0/><a2_0/> aesthetic".
